natural problem: Winnie has 17 red balloons, 33 white balloons, 65 green balloons, and 83 chartreuse balloons.  With no regard to color, Winnie gives each of her 8 nearest and dearest friends some balloons.  Each friend gets the same number of balloons and she hands out as many balloons as possible.  How many balloons does Winnie end up keeping for herself?
natural solution: We want to know the remainder when $17+33+65+83$ is divided by 8. The remainders of each of these numbers are easy to compute individually so we can say \[17+33+65+83\equiv1+1+1+3\equiv6\pmod8.\]Therefore Winnie has $\boxed{6}$ balloons left over after giving out her balloons.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red white green chartreuse friends keep :: nat
assumes h0 : "red = 17"
and h1 : "white = 33"
and h2 : "green = 65"
and h3 : "chartreuse = 83"
and h4 : "friends = 8"
and h5 : "red + white + green + chartreuse = friends * (red + white + green + chartreuse div friends) + keep"
shows  "keep = 6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Winnie has 17 red balloons, 33 white balloons, 65 green balloons, and 83 chartreuse balloons.  With no regard to color, Winnie gives each of her 8 nearest and dearest friends some balloons.  Each friend gets the same number of balloons and she hands out as many balloons as possible.  How many balloons does Winnie end up keeping for herself? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 We want to know the remainder when $17+33+65+83$ is divided by 8. The remainders of each of these numbers are easy to compute individually so we can say \[17+33+65+83\equiv1+1+1+3\equiv6\pmod8.\]Therefore Winnie has $\boxed{6}$ balloons left over after giving out her balloons.
 *)

theorem
fixes red white green chartreuse friends keep :: nat
assumes h0 : "red = 17"
and h1 : "white = 33"
and h2 : "green = 65"
and h3 : "chartreuse = 83"
and h4 : "friends = 8"
and h5 : "red + white + green + chartreuse = friends * (red + white + green + chartreuse div friends) + keep"
shows  "keep = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Assume there are 17 red, 33 white, 65 green, and 83 chartreuse items. These items are to be evenly distributed among 8 friends. If the items cannot be perfectly distributed and some items are kept, find the number of items kept. The final answer is 6.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red_balloon white_balloon green_balloon chartreuse_balloon friends balloons :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_balloon = 17"
and h1 : "white_balloon = 33"
and h2 : "green_balloon = 65"
and h3 : "chartreuse_balloon = 83"
and h4 : "friends = 8"
and h5 : "balloons = red_balloon + white_balloon + green_balloon + chartreuse_balloon"
and h6 : "\<exists> k. balloons = friends * k + 6"
shows  "balloons mod friends = 6"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Winnie has 17 red balloons, 33 white balloons, 65 green balloons, and 83 chartreuse balloons.  With no regard to color, Winnie gives each of her 8 nearest and dearest friends some balloons.  Each friend gets the same number of balloons and she hands out as many balloons as possible.  How many balloons does Winnie end up keeping for herself? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 We want to know the remainder when $17+33+65+83$ is divided by 8. The remainders of each of these numbers are easy to compute individually so we can say \[17+33+65+83\equiv1+1+1+3\equiv6\pmod8.\]Therefore Winnie has $\boxed{6}$ balloons left over after giving out her balloons.
 *)

theorem
fixes red_balloon white_balloon green_balloon chartreuse_balloon friends balloons :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_balloon = 17"
and h1 : "white_balloon = 33"
and h2 : "green_balloon = 65"
and h3 : "chartreuse_balloon = 83"
and h4 : "friends = 8"
and h5 : "balloons = red_balloon + white_balloon + green_balloon + chartreuse_balloon"
and h6 : "\<exists> k. balloons = friends * k + 6"
shows  "balloons mod friends = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: There are 17 red balloons, 33 white balloons, 65 green balloons, and 83 chartreuse balloons. If these balloons are distributed equally among 8 friends, with 6 balloons left over, how many balloons are there in total? The remainder when the total number of balloons is divided by the number of friends is 6.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red_balloons white_balloons green_balloons chartreuse_balloons friends :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_balloons = 17"
and h1 : "white_balloons = 33"
and h2 : "green_balloons = 65"
and h3 : "chartreuse_balloons = 83"
and h4 : "friends = 8"
and h5 : "\<forall> x. red_balloons mod friends = x \<and> white_balloons mod friends = x \<and> green_balloons mod friends = x \<and> chartreuse_balloons mod friends = x"
shows  "x = 6"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Winnie has 17 red balloons, 33 white balloons, 65 green balloons, and 83 chartreuse balloons.  With no regard to color, Winnie gives each of her 8 nearest and dearest friends some balloons.  Each friend gets the same number of balloons and she hands out as many balloons as possible.  How many balloons does Winnie end up keeping for herself? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 We want to know the remainder when $17+33+65+83$ is divided by 8. The remainders of each of these numbers are easy to compute individually so we can say \[17+33+65+83\equiv1+1+1+3\equiv6\pmod8.\]Therefore Winnie has $\boxed{6}$ balloons left over after giving out her balloons.
 *)

theorem
fixes red_balloons white_balloons green_balloons chartreuse_balloons friends :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_balloons = 17"
and h1 : "white_balloons = 33"
and h2 : "green_balloons = 65"
and h3 : "chartreuse_balloons = 83"
and h4 : "friends = 8"
and h5 : "\<forall> x. red_balloons mod friends = x \<and> white_balloons mod friends = x \<and> green_balloons mod friends = x \<and> chartreuse_balloons mod friends = x"
shows  "x = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: There are 17 red balloons, 33 white balloons, 65 green balloons, and 83 chartreuse balloons. These balloons will be divided equally among 8 friends. What is the remainder when the number of each color of balloons is divided by the number of friends? The final answer is 6.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red_balloons white_balloons green_balloons chartreuse_balloons friends :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_balloons = 17"
and h1 : "white_balloons = 33"
and h2 : "green_balloons = 65"
and h3 : "chartreuse_balloons = 83"
and h4 : "friends = 8"
shows  "(red_balloons + white_balloons + green_balloons + chartreuse_balloons) mod friends = 6"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Winnie has 17 red balloons, 33 white balloons, 65 green balloons, and 83 chartreuse balloons.  With no regard to color, Winnie gives each of her 8 nearest and dearest friends some balloons.  Each friend gets the same number of balloons and she hands out as many balloons as possible.  How many balloons does Winnie end up keeping for herself? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 We want to know the remainder when $17+33+65+83$ is divided by 8. The remainders of each of these numbers are easy to compute individually so we can say \[17+33+65+83\equiv1+1+1+3\equiv6\pmod8.\]Therefore Winnie has $\boxed{6}$ balloons left over after giving out her balloons.
 *)

theorem
fixes red_balloons white_balloons green_balloons chartreuse_balloons friends :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_balloons = 17"
and h1 : "white_balloons = 33"
and h2 : "green_balloons = 65"
and h3 : "chartreuse_balloons = 83"
and h4 : "friends = 8"
shows  "(red_balloons + white_balloons + green_balloons + chartreuse_balloons) mod friends = 6"

a_3.informal problem: You have 17 red balloons, 33 white balloons, 65 green balloons, and 83 chartreuse balloons. If you divide these balloons equally among 8 friends, how many balloons will you have left over? The final answer is 6.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red_balloons white_balloons green_balloons chartreuse_balloons friends :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_balloons = 17"
and h1 : "white_balloons = 33"
and h2 : "green_balloons = 65"
and h3 : "chartreuse_balloons = 83"
and h4 : "friends = 8"
and h5 : "let total_balloons = red_balloons + white_balloons + green_balloons + chartreuse_balloons in 
           \<forall> n. n <= total_balloons \<longrightarrow> total_balloons mod friends = n"
shows  "let total_balloons = red_balloons + white_balloons + green_balloons + chartreuse_balloons in 
        total_balloons mod friends = 6"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Winnie has 17 red balloons, 33 white balloons, 65 green balloons, and 83 chartreuse balloons.  With no regard to color, Winnie gives each of her 8 nearest and dearest friends some balloons.  Each friend gets the same number of balloons and she hands out as many balloons as possible.  How many balloons does Winnie end up keeping for herself? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 We want to know the remainder when $17+33+65+83$ is divided by 8. The remainders of each of these numbers are easy to compute individually so we can say \[17+33+65+83\equiv1+1+1+3\equiv6\pmod8.\]Therefore Winnie has $\boxed{6}$ balloons left over after giving out her balloons.
 *)

theorem
fixes red_balloons white_balloons green_balloons chartreuse_balloons friends :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_balloons = 17"
and h1 : "white_balloons = 33"
and h2 : "green_balloons = 65"
and h3 : "chartreuse_balloons = 83"
and h4 : "friends = 8"
and h5 : "let total_balloons = red_balloons + white_balloons + green_balloons + chartreuse_balloons in 
           \<forall> n. n <= total_balloons \<longrightarrow> total_balloons mod friends = n"
shows  "let total_balloons = red_balloons + white_balloons + green_balloons + chartreuse_balloons in 
        total_balloons mod friends = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: If there are 17 red balloons, 33 white balloons, 65 green balloons, and 83 chartreuse balloons, and these balloons are to be divided among 8 friends, what is the remainder when the total number of balloons is divided by the number of friends? The final answer is 6.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes balloons :: nat and friends :: nat
assumes h0 : "balloons = 17 + 33 + 65 + 83"
and h1 : "friends = 8"
and h2 : "balloons = friends * (balloons div friends) + (balloons mod friends)"
shows  "balloons mod friends = 6"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Winnie has 17 red balloons, 33 white balloons, 65 green balloons, and 83 chartreuse balloons.  With no regard to color, Winnie gives each of her 8 nearest and dearest friends some balloons.  Each friend gets the same number of balloons and she hands out as many balloons as possible.  How many balloons does Winnie end up keeping for herself? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 We want to know the remainder when $17+33+65+83$ is divided by 8. The remainders of each of these numbers are easy to compute individually so we can say \[17+33+65+83\equiv1+1+1+3\equiv6\pmod8.\]Therefore Winnie has $\boxed{6}$ balloons left over after giving out her balloons.
 *)

theorem
fixes balloons :: nat and friends :: nat
assumes h0 : "balloons = 17 + 33 + 65 + 83"
and h1 : "friends = 8"
and h2 : "balloons = friends * (balloons div friends) + (balloons mod friends)"
shows  "balloons mod friends = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: If there are 17, 33, 65, and 83 balloons divided among 8 friends, find the number of balloons that are left over after each friend receives an equal number. The final answer is 6.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red_balloons white_balloons green_balloons chartreuse_balloons friends :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_balloons = 17"
and h1 : "white_balloons = 33"
and h2 : "green_balloons = 65"
and h3 : "chartreuse_balloons = 83"
and h4 : "friends = 8"
and h5 : "let total_balloons = red_balloons + white_balloons + green_balloons + chartreuse_balloons in
           let balloons_per_friend = total_balloons div friends in
           let balloons_left = total_balloons - (balloons_per_friend * friends) in
           balloons_left = 6"
shows  "balloons_left = 6"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Winnie has 17 red balloons, 33 white balloons, 65 green balloons, and 83 chartreuse balloons.  With no regard to color, Winnie gives each of her 8 nearest and dearest friends some balloons.  Each friend gets the same number of balloons and she hands out as many balloons as possible.  How many balloons does Winnie end up keeping for herself? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 We want to know the remainder when $17+33+65+83$ is divided by 8. The remainders of each of these numbers are easy to compute individually so we can say \[17+33+65+83\equiv1+1+1+3\equiv6\pmod8.\]Therefore Winnie has $\boxed{6}$ balloons left over after giving out her balloons.
 *)

theorem
fixes red_balloons white_balloons green_balloons chartreuse_balloons friends :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_balloons = 17"
and h1 : "white_balloons = 33"
and h2 : "green_balloons = 65"
and h3 : "chartreuse_balloons = 83"
and h4 : "friends = 8"
and h5 : "let total_balloons = red_balloons + white_balloons + green_balloons + chartreuse_balloons in
           let balloons_per_friend = total_balloons div friends in
           let balloons_left = total_balloons - (balloons_per_friend * friends) in
           balloons_left = 6"
shows  "balloons_left = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: If you have 17 red balloons, 33 white balloons, 65 green balloons, and 83 chartreuse balloons, and you want to distribute these balloons equally among 8 friends, how many balloons will be left over after each friend has received an equal number of balloons? The final answer is 6.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red white green chartreuse nearest_dearest :: nat
assumes h0 : "red = 17"
and h1 : "white = 33"
and h2 : "green = 65"
and h3 : "chartreuse = 83"
and h4 : "nearest_dearest = 8"
shows  "(red + white + green + chartreuse) mod nearest_dearest = 6"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Winnie has 17 red balloons, 33 white balloons, 65 green balloons, and 83 chartreuse balloons.  With no regard to color, Winnie gives each of her 8 nearest and dearest friends some balloons.  Each friend gets the same number of balloons and she hands out as many balloons as possible.  How many balloons does Winnie end up keeping for herself? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof

 *)

theorem
fixes red white green chartreuse nearest_dearest :: nat
assumes h0 : "red = 17"
and h1 : "white = 33"
and h2 : "green = 65"
and h3 : "chartreuse = 83"
and h4 : "nearest_dearest = 8"
shows  "(red + white + green + chartreuse) mod nearest_dearest = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: If you have 17 red, 33 white, 65 green, and 83 chartreuse items, what is the remainder when the total number of items is divided by 8? The final answer is 6.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red white green chartreuse friends balloons_kept :: nat
assumes h0 : "red = 17"
and h1 : "white = 33"
and h2 : "green = 65"
and h3 : "chartreuse = 83"
and h4 : "friends = 8"
and h5 : "(red + white + green + chartreuse) mod friends = balloons_kept"
shows  "balloons_kept = 6"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Winnie has 17 red balloons, 33 white balloons, 65 green balloons, and 83 chartreuse balloons.  With no regard to color, Winnie gives each of her 8 nearest and dearest friends some balloons.  Each friend gets the same number of balloons and she hands out as many balloons as possible.  How many balloons does Winnie end up keeping for herself? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 We want to know the remainder when $17+33+65+83$ is divided by 8. The remainders of each of these numbers are easy to compute individually so we can say \[17+33+65+83\equiv1+1+1+3\equiv6\pmod8.\]Therefore Winnie has $\boxed{6}$ balloons left over after giving out her balloons.
 *)

theorem
fixes red white green chartreuse friends balloons_kept :: nat
assumes h0 : "red = 17"
and h1 : "white = 33"
and h2 : "green = 65"
and h3 : "chartreuse = 83"
and h4 : "friends = 8"
and h5 : "(red + white + green + chartreuse) mod friends = balloons_kept"
shows  "balloons_kept = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A group of 8 friends have 17 red, 33 white, 65 green, and 83 chartreuse balloons. If they distribute all the balloons equally among them, how many balloons will be left undistributed? The final answer is 6.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red_balloons white_balloons green_balloons chartreuse_balloons friends left_over :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_balloons = 17"

and h2 : "green_balloons = 65"
and h3 : "chartreuse_balloons = 83"
and h4 : "friends = 8"
and h5 : "(red_balloons + white_balloons + green_balloons + chartreuse_balloons) mod friends = left_over"
shows  "left_over = 6"

(* ### Problem
 Winnie has 17 red balloons, 33 white balloons, 65 green balloons, and 83 chartreuse balloons.  With no regard to color, Winnie gives each of her 8 nearest and dearest friends some balloons.  Each friend gets the same number of balloons and she hands out as many balloons as possible.  How many balloons does Winnie end up keeping for herself? The final Answer is 6

 *)

theorem
fixes red_balloons white_balloons green_balloons chartreuse_balloons friends left_over :: nat

and h1 : "white_balloons = 33"
and h2 : "green_balloons = 65"

and h5 : "(red_balloons + white_balloons + green_balloons + chartreuse_balloons) mod friends = left_over"

a_9.informal problem: You have 17 red balloons, 33 white balloons, 65 green balloons and 83 chartreuse balloons. If you have 8 friends and you want to divide all the balloons evenly among your friends, how many balloons will be left over? The final answer is 6.
